newsitem.title: USA: Clark disputes allegations refinery unsafe.
newsitem.headline: Clark disputes allegations refinery unsafe.

text.p: Clark Refining and Marketing Co refinery manager Bob Martindale said the company's local refinery is operating safely and called a move by Illinois regulators to close down the facility "unwarranted and unjustified."

"The Blue Island (Ill.) refinery is safe and has been demonstrating its safety day by day. The nature of Saturday's incident has been exaggerated," Martindale said on Tuesday in a statement released by the independent refining and marketing company.

An explosion and fire in a propane pipeline rocked the 80,515 barrel per day refinery on Saturday, shutting down a processing unit used to refine premium unleaded gasoline. No one was injured and there was no damage outside the refinery, the company said.

Following the explosion, Illinois Attorney General Jim Ryan sought a court order to temporarily shut down the refinery until the company can demonstrate the facility can be operated safely. A hearing was set for Wednesday in Cook County Circuit Court.

The Blue Island refinery has been under scrutiny by state regulators following two headline-grabbing accidents last year. On March 13, 1995, an explosion in a processing unit killed two workers and injured three others. In May 1995, fifteen pounds of hydrofluroic acid leaked from an alkylation unit and floated over a nearby high school, where 25 students complained of lightheadedness and related symptoms.
Martindale said Clark has implemented new safety programs since those incidents. "As significantly, during this time, we also had an outstanding environmental safety record," he said.
Clark is a unit of Clark USA Inc which is 49 percent owned by The Horsham Corp of Canada.
